title: 115_s1072
content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans under certain conditions. Services covered may include care for a dependent while the homeless veteran receives services from the grant recipient. Partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. Section 2022A of Title 38, United States Code, authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary can fund general legal services for these individuals through these partnerships, subject to the availability of funds. The Secretary can partner with public or private entities to fund general legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Partnerships should be distributed across the United States, including rural communities, tribal lands, Native Americans, and tribal organizations. Partnerships under this section aim to be distributed equitably across the United States, including rural communities, tribal lands, Native Americans, and tribal organizations. Legal services provided address the needs of homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including housing-related legal services. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include housing-related legal services, family law assistance, and income support services. Legal services provided include defense in landlord-tenant cases, foreclosure proceedings, family law assistance for reunification, child support, divorce, and estate planning, income support for obtaining public benefits, and criminal defense for matters related to homelessness to reduce recidivism and facilitate reentry into employment or housing. Legal services related to criminal defense, including defense in matters symptomatic of homelessness, such as outstanding warrants, fines, and driver's license revocation, to reduce recidivism and facilitate reentry obstacles in employment or housing. Such other legal services as deemed appropriate and necessary by the Secretary. Consultation with public and private entities for assistance in identifying and contacting. The Secretary may require entities in partnerships to submit reports. Consultation with public and private entities for assistance in identifying and contacting organizations. Other legal services as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The Secretary may require entities in partnerships to submit reports on legal services provided to homeless veterans. This includes assistance in identifying organizations and coordinating outreach relationships. Additionally, the Secretary may request reports on services for veterans at risk of homelessness. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans and partnerships with public and private entities for legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness are key initiatives outlined in the legislation. Section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include eligibility criteria for veterans receiving housing assistance or care in specific settings. The eligibility criteria for veterans receiving housing assistance or care in specific settings include assistance under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 or care in domiciliaries, therapeutic residences, community residential care, or other settings coordinated by the Secretary. The eligibility criteria for veterans receiving housing assistance or care in specific settings include assistance under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 or care in domiciliaries, therapeutic residences, community residential care, or other settings coordinated by the Secretary. The Secretary may disregard breaks in the continuity of care when determining if a veteran has received assistance for 60 consecutive days. The Secretary may provide funds for a grant and per diem provider in a specific setting for veterans. When determining if a veteran has received assistance for 60 consecutive days, breaks in care not caused by the veteran may be disregarded. SEC. 5 amends Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d). SEC. 6 extends the authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. SEC. 6 extends the authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing by amending section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code to allocate $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2017. Training entities for provision of supportive services are also extended through 2017. SEC. 7 requires the Comptroller General to study Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will study Department of Veterans Affairs programs assisting homeless veterans, assessing their effectiveness and reviewing efforts to improve services for female veterans. SEC. 8. REPEAL OF REQUIREMENT FOR ANNUAL REPORTS ON ASSISTANCE TO HOMELESS VETERANS. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, is repealed. The table of sections in chapter 20 of such title is amended accordingly.
